awd_titl_txt: Conference: Workshop on Data-driven Signal Processing, NextG Communications, and Networking
awd_abstract_narration:
Developments in Machine Learning (ML) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) continue to dramatically transform data processing, interpretation, and inference across various domains. These advancements prompt a reassessment of techniques and technologies in signal processing, communications, and networking through a data-centric lens.

The forthcoming workshop, scheduled for May 17-18, 2024 at the Twin Cities campus of the University of Minnesota, explores the promises and impact of the integration of ML/AI in Signal Processing, Next Generation (NextG) Communications, and Networking. The workshop will focus on pioneering methodologies to model and govern interconnected systems. It will serve as a platform for interdisciplinary scientific exchange and visioning among field-shaping researchers and practitioners. It will provide opportunities for future collaborations enabling progress in data-driven approaches to signal processing, NextG communications, networking and their applications. The videos of the headline and expert presentations and panel discussions will be made publicly available on the workshop website, and the workshop report will be disseminated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of the workshop, titled "Data-driven Signal Processing, NextG Communications, and Networking," held at the University of Minnesota campus on May 17-18, 2024, was to discuss foundational topics on Signal Processing, NextG Communications, and Networking through a data-driven lens. The event aimed to introduce innovative methods for modeling and governing interconnected systems by incorporating AI into signal processing, NextG communication, and networking technologies. Additionally, the workshop sought to promote workforce development and empower next-generation technologies, fostering societal advancements. 

This workshop provided a platform for interdisciplinary scientific exchange, bringing together researchers, students and practitioners to advance data-driven approaches in signal processing, NextG communication, and networking. Approximately 80 experts from various fields—including signal processing, machine learning, wireless networking, optimization, statistics, and computing—participated, representing academia, government, and industry. These attendees engaged in discussions on cutting-edge applications of data-driven approaches, including adaptive and socially intelligent networks, 6G communication, beam management in 5G, optimization of power grids, sparse signal recovery, and graph learning for autonomous systems. The workshop featured 12 invited talks delivered by world-renowned academic and industry leaders in data science and three engaging panel discussions. The thematic areas included Data-driven Signal Processing, NextG Wireless Communications, and AI for Grids, Graphs, and Networks. Highlights included Ali H. Sayed's talk on adaptive and socially intelligent networks, Yoram Bresler's presentation on data-driven performance bounds for parameter estimation, Arogyaswami Paulraj’s talk on mobile wireless technology from 2G to 5G, Robert Heath's discussion on data-driven beam management for 5G and beyond, and Steven Low's exploration of optimization, learning, and control in power grids. Panels addressed key issues such as the evolution of signal processing, challenges in NextG networks, and AI's transformative impact on power grids and recommendation systems. Esteemed panelists included Vincent Poor, Jitendra Tugnait, Petar Djuric, Anna Scaglione, Hao Zhu, George Karypis, and Antonio Marques. 

The workshop proved to be a significant milestone in advancing knowledge and fostering collaboration in data-driven signal processing, NextG communications, and networking. Through a combination of expert-led plenary talks, dynamic panel discussions, and interactive brainstorming sessions, participants not only shared cutting-edge research but also identified emerging challenges and opportunities in the field. The exchange of ideas between academia, industry, and government representatives stimulated innovative approaches and set the stage for transformative research and technological breakthroughs.
